context: Hallucinations and smells were kind of working, right? Why the bath?
response: Hypnosis gave me a nose picker. Smells set off hallucinations. Sensory deprivation should get the brain into an alpha-theta phase. Didn't you see Altered States?

context: I don't think I was Even born when that movie was out.
response: Well then you're too young to be a doctor. That movie was released in 1980.

context: That was twenty-eight years ago.
response: No, it wasn't, shut up.

context: Did you just forget what year it is?
response: No. I just remembered how old I am. I need to give my brain time to transition so I can embrace my inner monkey. Or maybe I don't. Give me some physostigmine. It crosses the blood-brain barrier.

context: And act like a nerve gas, stop your heart, you'll go to heaven and be omniscient. Good idea. Not going to happen.
response: Don't do anything. Even if I escape. Eat a goat. Get shot by police "

context: I didn't know you rode the bus.
response: I used to drive home after getting drunk, but some mothers got MAD-D. What are you doing here? You weren't on the bus with me.

context: Then I guess this isn't a memory. It's a fantasy.
response: If it's a fantasy, you'd be wearing... This.

context: You're convinced your Patient is dying, and you want to waste your time with a sex fantasy?
response: Don't blame me. Blame my gender.

context: Well, I'm not here to indulge that. I'm here to help you figure out what symptom you saw. Your Patient was driving the bus, so all you could see "
response: Why can't you do both?

context: Your Patient was driving the bus, so all you could see was him sitting down. Most likely facing forward.
response: From behind, I saw his earlobes wiggling. Or his head bobbing. But not that.

context: It's not fatal in adults.
response: Yeah, yeah, yeah. He's an adult, very good point. Keep going.

context: Hey, over here. Remember me? I'm the sick guy.

context: Was it the blood dripping from my ear?
response: That doesn't make sense. Because your shirt wasn't stained. And because that was me.

context: I could have had a subtle hemiballismus, indicating the early stages of Huntington's.
response: Huntington's wouldn't explain the abdominal pain. And it's only on the table because we're thinking of Thirteen.

context: A shuffling gait could suggest Parkinson's.
response: Except there's no such thing as shuffling sitting.

context: Welcome back. I'm Nurse Dickerson.
response: I don't need your name. And I got your profession from your super competent technique of melting my retinas.

context: Verbal faculties seem to be intact. Do you remember passing out?
response: I remember puking on Cuddy's shoes. Ow.

context: Yeah. Skull fractures tend to hurt.
response: It'd hurt a lot less if you didn't swipe my pain pills.

context: Dr. Cuddy's orders. Wants me to regulate the amount "

response: How did you eliminate Parkinson's?

response: Then if she's wrong, that makes this phone call that much more exciting. What about hepatic fibrosis?

context: It could be thyrotoxic periodic paralysis.
response: Did I mention this diagnosis needs to make sense?

context: Why doesn't it make sense? The bus driver's Asian, his potassium is slightly low "
response: If he got paralysed while driving the bus, don't you think I would have gotten off at the next stop?

context: Not if the next stop was at a 90 degree angle into an SUV.
response: The bus would have slowed, I would have noticed "

context: TPP has all the confirmed symptoms. There's no downside to testing.
response: Genetic test is too slow. Run the bagel test!

context: I told you not to lock the door.
response: Still wiping! Put the phone up to bus driver's grill.

context: Who are you talking to?
response: My large colon. TPP is not consistent with your Patient's laboured breathing.

context: Did you take my cell phone?
response: My large colon did. I'm negotiating its release.

context: The test worked. He collapsed.
response: You're half right. He's wheezing, isn't he?

context: It must be a pulmonary embolism.
response: So why haven't you pushed a vial of tPA?

response: At the tail end of me Patiently explaining how you idiots were idiots.

context: We pushed tPA ten minutes ago.
response: That means it's not a clot.

context: Get him to the OR to suck it out.
response: Must have just screwed up the intubation. Seal's good.

context: I didn't bring you back here so you could stage a coup!
response: Listen to me. Dental air drill pushed an air bubble into his gums. Dislodged while he was driving, and caused a myoclonic jerk. That's what I must have seen. Then it hit his spine, his liver, and now his lungs.

context: Dr. Hadley, open the door.
response: I'm not plumping his pillows here. I'm putting him in the Trendelenburg position to move the bubble to the apex of his heart so you can suck it out, now get the damn syringe.

context: The O2 sats. There was an air bubble. He's okay.
response: The other nurse always used to tuck me in.

context: In the ointment. So there's something wrong. There's some detail I'm not noticing that's spoiling the big picture.
response: Is this significant? Or is this dream just going in a different direction now?

context: I guess that depends. What are you going to do with that?
response: I have to tie this around you.

context: It's not over. I saved the wrong person.
response: This wasn't just a dream or a fantasy, or a drug-induced trip to Wonderland.

context: So the bus driver with the air bubble was just a coincidence?
response: Nope. I got the causation flipped. The bubble didn't cause the crash. The crash caused the bubble to dislodge. There was no myoclonic jerk. I saw something else in someone else.

context: Elevated heart rate, BP... Which is exactly why you need to stop.
response: Instead of sleeping, I'm going to be pacing around this apartment trying to decipher those visions.

context: Why does this matter so much?
response: I don't know. Heart rate?

context: I'm not going to call in crash victims because you've gone insane.
response: Maybe I don't need the actual victims.

context: Maybe I don't need the actual victims.
response: Who's playing Anne McKeehan? Right here. Jane Doe 2 from Princeton General. Right here. You two, that's right. Goth kid. Yeah. At the back on the right. Yeah. Here. Okay...

context: You think that staring at pictures on our shirts is going to be more effective than hypnosis?
response: Well, if only you'd stop talking, the re-enactment could stimulate activity in my hippocampus and parahippocampal cortex.

context: Are you crazy? Alzheimer's drugs will make your brain go into overdrive.
response: That's the point. It'll speed up my neuronal firing. Turn up the voltage on my memory.

context: And blow out your heart. How Many did you take?
response: Just now? Or including the ones I took on the ride over?

context: You beliEve in reason above all else. There must be a reason.
response: You have something to tell me.

context: You know who I am.
response: If I did, I'd be passed out in bed instead of OD'ing on physostigmine on the 6th Street cross-town.

context: Because you don't know the answer.
response: And if I don't, you don't. But you know the clues.

context: You almost kill yourself, and all we're getting is drug-induced fantasies.
response: Have you spoken to her?

context: She's pRobably working. She's... She's been on call. I called her... She didn't call... I... I... How could she...
response: I don't know... Jane Doe 2.

context: Female. Late twenties. Kidney damage. Does Amber have a birthmark on her right shoulder blade?
response: She was on the bus with me. She's the one who's dying.

context: I don't know how I got here. I saw a symptom before the crash.
response: Why was I taking the bus?

context: Taxing an already injured brain.
response: Someone is dying because I can't remember.

context: Her heart won't stop racing. No idea what's causing it.
response: Sure it wasn't the bus that landed on her?

context: Three critical Patients ahead of her. We'll have her in within the hour.
response: We're fifteen minutes away from Princeton Plainsboro by ambulance.

context: You wanna move her? Her heart rate is a hundred and thirty.
response: She's hemodynamically stable. We're moving her.

context: Why was she on the bus?
response: I don't know. If she had any underlying condition, the accident could have exacerbated it.

context: Why were you with her?
response: I don't know! I'm not hiding anything. I just don't remember. What else could damage her heart?

context: I don't know! I'm not hiding anything. I just don't remember. What else could damage her heart?
response: Wilson, don't get lost! I'm barely coherent. I need your help right now.

context: Wait, wait, wait! Protective hypothermia.
response: You wanna freeze her? Her heart's not beating.

context: Her heart's already damaged. If you restart it, it'll keep racing, shoot off free radicals, and kill her brain. We ice her down, put her on bypass until you've diagnosed her.
response: This is not a solution. All you're doing is pressing pause.

context: Why are we doing this?
response: Bought us time to think.

context: Bought us time to think.
response: The trauma must have stimulated a pre-existing heart condition.

context: Autoimmune congenital anomaly, blood clotting disorder, lead poisoning...
response: Great! Let's explore that. Quick, get her on panacea.

context: EKG, nope. Heart's in the off position. Thallium uptake scan? Useless on a cold heart.
response: Yeah, we get it. Her heart's not beating. It's gonna make it harder to diagnose. On the other hand, she's not gonna die while you're whining about it. What else?

context: Why not cyanide? He's a mess. He needs to sleep.
response: I had a heart attack this morning. Can't do any more drugs till lunch. Get her an angiogram. Could show damage Even in a stopped heart. Rest of you search her apartment. Toxins, heavy metals, drugs, anything that might make her heart race.

context: I need to know if there's anything medically relevant that you couldn't share publicly.
response: Is this a Philanderers Anonymous intervention?

context: You were obviously drinking last night. Maybe you took Amber to a bar.
response: I left here on my motorcycle alone.

context: You ended up drunk on a bus together. Maybe you met Amber in the bar.
response: I was not having an affair with her.

context: You can't really say that if you don't remember.
response: I lost four hours, not four months.

context: Don't worry, you're just dreaming.
response: What symptom did I see in you? A myoclonic jerk...

context: What did we do last night?
response: Was I meeting you for a drink?

context: You need to rest. I have yet to hear about any study linking electricity and rest.
response: Deep brain stimulation. It's been proven. Electrical impulses applied directly to the hypothalamus could evoke detailed memories.

context: It's gonna be okay. I'm here with you.
response: The team has found something. Can you ask her if we can be excused?

context: Sh-she'd have to be an addict to take enough for it to damage her heart. I'd know.
response: Did you know that she was hiding them in her vitamins?

context: No, we've been over this. Starting her heart could cause brain damage, could burn out the heart muscle.
response: Test her heart without starting it. Crack her chest open, reach a finger inside the pulmonary vein, run it across the valve.

context: If this were any other Patient...
response: If the valve is calcified, that's our answer. That's our cure. Go.

context: If the valve is calcified, that's our answer. That's our cure. Go.
response: "Thirteen". Who found the diet pills?

context: "Thirteen". Who found the diet pills?
response: You didn't Even go in the bathroom, did you? You're suddenly mute in the differentials. A blow-up doll would be more useful. And yes, that's the first time I've Ever implied something negative about a blow-up doll.

context: You didn't Even go in the bathroom, did you? You're suddenly mute in the differentials. A blow-up doll would be more useful. And yes, that's the first time I've Ever implied something negative about a blow-up doll.
response: Normally, I'd be fascinated. Today, don't care. Get over whatEver it is and do your job.

context: And the cardio fits just as well. But there's no way we can tell, since we can't take her temperature.
response: I had a dream. She was pouring me a glass. And since I'm a scotch-, beer-, gin-, and rum-Man...

context: Amber doesn't Even drink sherry. House. Can we get back...?
response: If she did drink sherry, it would mean nothing. Since she doesn't, my subconscious is obviously trying to make some other point.

context: A coaster with "Sharrie's Bar ". A glass of scotch is placed on it, by the Bartender.
response: Wilson's right. We need to make her colder.

context: Putting more ice on her is just delaying the diagnosis.
response: Not on, in. Fill in her lungs with slurry.

context: She sneezed. I gave her a napkin.
response: Did you see the color of the sputum?

context: I assume sputum means snot. Look, I see a lot of drunk Parkcks in here. I didn't have time to stop and analyze the color of your girlfriend's boogers.
response: She's not my girlfriend, genius.

context: Last night, she was your girlfriend.
response: Blood in the sputum could mean parasites. Any recent travel?

context: If he had a brain, he wouldn't be tending bar.
response: Sneezing's a new symptom. Let's assume the runny nose means an infection.

context: I was six years old. I used to like helping out in my parents' store after school. Guy walks in to Rob the place. Ends up shooting them both. Wasn't fair. Took years, but I had to accept that's just the way it was. So you gonna help me fill her lungs up or not?
response: Tell me that the liver biopsy showed infiltrates, minor inflammation.

context: Hepatitis B is a lame diagnosis.
response: Oh, God. I get less rest when I'm asleep.

context: I rise from the dead, and that's the reaction I get?
response: I'm sorry. If I had known, I would have started a breakaway Jewish sect. Hep B fits.

context: I'm sorry. If I had known, I would have started a breakaway Jewish sect. Hep B fits.
response: Why are you doing that?

context: We're about to start a second course of interferon.
response: Which she might not need once you turn her over. Small of her back.

context: A rash. How'd you know what was on the small of her back?
response: Either I'm still asleep, or I'm starting to remember.

context: Wouldn't speed up her heart.
response: Yes, the symptom that I saw on the bus was a rare interferon allergy that flares up two days before you take it.

context: How did you see the rash down there?
response: I don't know. Maybe she leaned over.

context: Maybe it's not a rash at all. It could be an abscess.
response: "Thirteen", stick a needle in there. If there's pus, Foreman's right.

context: "Thirteen", stick a needle in there. If there's pus, Foreman's right.
response: I'm not asking you to stick a needle all the way through. Taub, you do it.

context: We're nEver one hundred percent certain.
response: Run the blood cultures. After we get confirmation, then we'll restart her heart.

context: He's wrong. And you know he's wrong. You can't change your mind just because a family member starts crying. They're always scared.
response: I said, run the blood cultures.

context: 'S not guilt. That just leaves fear. Young Woman dying. Young doctor dying, in fact. That sound familiar?
response: By not getting tested? Dealing with it by not dealing with it. It's clearly working beautifully.

context: By not getting tested? Dealing with it by not dealing with it. It's clearly working beautifully.
response: My grandson gave me a mug that says that. Okay. Enough hand-holding. Deal with it. Get back in there. Or pack up your stuff.

context: Heart, liver, rash, and now her brain.
response: Autoimmune fits best. Crash trauma could've set it off. Start her on prednisone, then we'll warm her up again.

context: Cuddy's right. I was afraid to do anything. I thought if Everything just stopped, it would be okay.
response: And it's gonna be. Taub's starting the treatment. We're doing Everything...

context: Not Everything. Before you warm her up... You said you wanted to try deep brain stimulation.
response: But there's no reason. We know the symptom, we know what I saw.

context: What if it's not the rash? What if you noticed the rash in the ambulance or when we were putting her on bypass? What if there is still something else stuck inside your head?
response: You think I should risk my life to save Amber's.

context: Who was talking? Is Amber there?
response: You're supposed to be jolting my hypothalamus, not petting it.

context: We don't want to overload it.
response: As long as I'm risking my life, I might as well be watParkng a talkie.

context: You're not getting them back.
response: Hey! You take my keys, you gotta give me a phone call.

context: I told her to find you. Have you pick me up.
response: I said to find Wilson.

context: The obstinate drunk thing is not flattering. C'mon. You called for a ride.
response: Drink your drink, or I'll drink 'em both.

context: House, what are you doing? You can barely walk.
response: Go home. I'll take the bus.

context: Yeah, I'm an idiot that way.
response: You doing this for me or for Wilson?

context: Ugh, damn, do you have a Kleenex?
response: I got a sleEve. I got two, actually.

context: Is that it? The flu? Is there any rare complication?
response: No. It would explain the rash, but nothing else. Unless...

context: AMantadine binds with proteins. Dialysis can't clear it out of the blood.
response: There's nothing we can do.

context: I thought you said you needed 8 weeks of rehab. You should have been back here
response: If I'd come back sooner, I'd only be able to run 6 miles. I nEver would have made it in. What have you got for me?

context: You're completely pain free? The ketamine treatment can wear off.
response: It's been 2 months. It's not wearing off. What have you got for me?

context: It can take as long as--
response: Why are we having this discussion? Want to hear me thank you again? Thank you Dr Cuddy. Not just for removing the bullet, but thank you for putting me in a ketamine-induced coma and changing my life. Happy? I am.

context: Middle-aged Man: had hair transplant about 2 months ago--
response: Infection throwing clots, you're an idiot. Except you're not an idiot, and she's holding a file for a 26-yr-old female, what have you really got for me?

context: Girl was doing an inverted yoga pose, neck snapped, paralyzed from the neck down except the x-rays show no evidence of spinal injury. And she's cute.
response: Oh, well played sir! What about Stephen Hawking trying to do the 500 butterfly?

context: Forget it - brain cancer, brain surgery - there's nothing left to diagnose. I would take the other one.
response: Hmm... I'll take them both.

context: You don't think he had brain cancer?
response: Of course he had brain cancer; Even oncologists don't screw up for 8 years.

context: Then why are you taking the case?
response: Guy tried to kill himself.

context: The guy had cancer, he's a lump; he hasn't been able to touch his wife, speak to his kids.
response: He's been in that chair for 8 years, his muscles have atrophied. Maybe I can help him with the pain. Isn't that enough of a reason to want to help?

context: Then why am I taking this case?
response: Let's start with the cute paraplegic.

context: Uhh... you could take a whole 2 minutes to ease into being back.
response: Taken a whole month to ease back, 8 weeks is the maximum rehab time for a gunshot wound to the stomach and neck. So, go.

context: We heard they nEver found the guy. There's no new leads?
response: What? You think he might have shot this Patient too? Would explain her symptoms!

context: See? It's not so difficult.
response: It's not MS. She had no symptoms before she climbed on to her head. Unless she's been upside-down for the last 10 years, MS ain't it.

context: The leg looks fine. You totally pain free?
response: When did this turn into 'what did you do over your summer vacation'?

context: I asked Cuddy to replace the carpet.
response: No, I like the carpet. What did you do over the summer?

context: You don't think that's from the pool he drank?
response: Give him an O2 mask. His leg muscles have atrophied, tendons have shortened from disuse causing intense pain. Tendon surgery will make him more comfortable.

context: My dad wouldn't kill himself.
response: You haven't spoken to him in over 6 years.

context: Look, he must have been confused. It must have been an accident.
response: Hope it was a suicide attempt. If he was trying to kill himself then he knows how miserable his life is, means there's still something there to kill; means your dad's still there.

context: We were doing the EMG but we nEver got past the insertion of the conduction pin. Did she just say thank you?
response: I loaned her some money. What went wrong?

context: You're not going to tell me why she thanked you?
response: You're not going to tell me what went right?

context: You did something for which she is grateful and you're... embarrassed?
response: For you. Saw you coming up, thought you were a 14-yr-old boy, I set her straight.

context: I'm not telling you what went wrong - or right, until you tell me why she said thank you.
response: Ohhh, you got me. You know I need to know, I'm so going to fold. Except you're forgetting, there's one thing I can do now.

context: Ok, this is Dr. House. House, this is Caren--
response: Pleasure's all mine, what happened?

context: When we inserted the conduction pin, she flinched.
response: She flinched! Did you hear?

context: Does that mean I'm getting better?
response: How big is a flinch? Bigger than a twitch? Smaller than a spasm? You smoke?

context: I know it's hypocritical but--
response: Not at all, the world sees your legs, no one's checking out your lungs.

context: It's a good thing we didn't. Tightness in her chest, she can't breathe, it could be pleural effusion.
response: Right. Either that or she's holding her breath like a 4-yr-old.

context: Right. Either that or she's holding her breath like a 4-yr-old.
response: Relax. I'm not going to burn you again. I'm going to STAB YOU! Look, either you're faking, or you've got a pleural effusion - that's a build-up of fluid around the lungs which is very serious - and I would have no choice but to stab you in the back with this needle and suck all the fluid out of you. So--

context: We should give her a local.
response: That would defeat the point of me being nasty. Ready? Down.

context: Or vasculitis would also explain the effusion.
response: But not the paralysis. Let's assume that she wasn't faking it.

context: She moved, therefore she could move. She wasn't paralyzed.
response: Ehh... doesn't mean she was faking, could have been a delusion. Now, either she was faking, and coincidentally got a real cardiac pRoblem at the exact same time, or it's a delusion and the fake paralysis is a real neurological symptom.

context: And she's been scanned up and down, it's all clean.
response: So, open her up, and find it.

context: No, I mean all the other doctors, all they did was obsess on the... the cancer, the treatment, the damage... just trying to fix him. You're the first doctor that's Ever given a damn about the quality of his life.
response: His heart rate's come down, the morphine worked I was right.

context: What a touParkng moment. That's why we become doctors. For those rare moments when our hearts are warm--
response: Would you like to get a drink?

context: Are you serious or are you just trying to change the subject?
response: No, I'm serious. I drink, you drink. We could do it at the same time, same table. Do you eat? We could do that too. I mean, if the answer's no that's cool but...

context: No, I... it's just... you're just coming off the surgery and you're not yourself yet and I work for you and Even though last year's... you're smiling! I'm saying no and you're smiling!
response: Oh, don't take it personally. Its just coz you're full of crap. You have no interest in going out with me. Maybe you did, when I couldn't walk and I was a sick puppy that you could nurture back to health. Now that I'm healthy, there's nothing in it for you.

context: There's no tumor. Her platelets are normal, scans--
response: What's the worst that can happen? I paralyze her. She won't Even notice.

context: Her Lawyers might. You're not doing the surgery. And lower the morphine on your other Patient.
response: Fine, I'll lower it. If you'll let me do the surgery.

context: What? You want a trade? We're not swapping a couple of goats for your help putting up a barn.
response: You want something, I want something. We compromise. It's the grown-up way to resolve our differences.

context: You really don't give a crap, do you?
response: Does that make me evil?

context: The fifth lEvel of happiness involves creation. Changing lives.
response: Sixth lEvel is heroin; sEventh lEvel is you going away.

context: The room's no longer sterile.
response: True, it's not the most interesting reason. That is not a sexy big toe. You'd nEver put that in your mouth.

context: What the hell has that got to do with--
response: Told you it was interesting; it gets Even better.

context: The uh... nurse changed his morphine, I thought you were worried about--
response: It's just post-op discomfort. He's ready to go home.

context: Well, you took away his pain and that, that changes a lot.
response: Why don't you put him in some sort of... facility? Some place without a pool.

context: Yeah. I could dump him there, except he's my husband. He's my son's father.
response: Right. Kids need a dad; someone to play catch with. Talk about girls.

context: I'm taking care of him for the same reason you helped us.
response: Some guy shot you and you hallucinated?

context: Yoga girl walked out of here 2 hours ago, you fixed her.
response: Not her, the other guy.

context: He had brain cancer; they removed it 8 years ago. His condition's been the same Ever since.
response: Until last night, he spoke.

context: You want us to dissect 8 years of medical history with grunting in the differential?
response: Sounds good. Call me when you're done.

context: You're fabricating a mystery because you're bored.
response: I am not bored. Damn it.

context: You didn't tell the wife it was only a grunt?
response: Of course not, because then she would nEver have consented to a bunch of dangerous tests. I don't remember you being this bitchy.

context: The Vicodin dulled it, in the sober light of day I'm a buzz kill. You're giving false hope to a family that's been wrecked. Don't torture them, let it go, tell the wife it was only a grunt, tell her to go home.
response: Can't let her down like that, pumped her up with too much false hope. Oh! I stuck that primo! How rad am I?

context: No, creatinine and BUN were both normal.
response: Not the kidney part, the pain part. Abdominal pain plus all that stuff could equal a pancreatic cyst.

context: Perfect, you Managed to pick the one symptom he nEver had. Abdominal pain.
response: It's the first symptom on the board. Grunt.

context: Grunting isn't pathognomonic for abdominal pain.
response: No, traditional diagnostic marker is compression of the diaphragm, vibration of the larynx leading to the audible sound 'I have a pain in my abdomen'.

context: Richard's symptoms are culled from 8 years of medical history. They're not patterned. These are random individual Events over time.
response: Illnesses have incubation periods. Do an upper endoscopic ultrasound.

context: His throat will collapse, muscle degeneration in his neck won't tolerate the scope, it's an automatic trach!
response: You're talking about him like he's an invalid.

context: We trached him, endoscopically removed the pRobe and he's breathing again. So, all in all, great idea.
response: Get a look at the pancreas before the world ended?

context: Which means barring anything else, meaning you, he can go home tomorrow.
response: This Man nearly died. How can you discharge him?

context: You stick something down someone's throat, they gag, spasm, which he did. It took us a half an hour to get that thing out.
response: Except that our Patient's throat was sedated. Which means the brain should have sent a signal not to do anything. This could be cancer, or some bizarre neuro-degeneration, Even a new type of vasculitis--

context: It's interesting only if you're right; if you're wrong we're torturing this guy to amuse you.
response: Half hour to remove the pRobe?

context: There are no lesions on his brain, nothing to interrupt the new orders.
response: All it takes is one wire down.

context: You have no evidence of any wires down.
response: A few micro-tumors on the meninges, suddenly you're choking to death.

context: Because that wouldn't be interesting. You can get permission this time.
response: The brain is enclosed in a sac called the meninges--

context: So what, more surgery? More radiation?
response: Might not be the worst thing. If this isn't just ancient history then maybe it's something we can correct. Might Even get some brain function back.

context: You're lucky he didn't die.
response: I'm lucky? He's the one who didn't die.

context: We told you he'd hemorrhage.
response: Told me he'd bleed into his brain, not out of his ear.

context: We did a dangerous test and something bad happened, that's all this is.
response: Give me a tour of the brain, Foreman. Walk me through the scans. 1998, what happened?

context: 5 cm grade 4 astrocytoma between the parietal--

response: Which one of you two gave her an aspirin?

response: She's lying. She's angry. 'Cause you kidnapped her kid. She'll be angrier if the kid dies.

context: She's fifteen. She's very responsible.
response: She a fifteen-year-old pharmacist? Or is it just some kid from down the street, who needed twenty bucks for lip gloss and couple of Tiger Beats?

context: She a fifteen-year-old pharmacist? Or is it just some kid from down the street, who needed twenty bucks for lip gloss and couple of Tiger Beats?
response: Put your kid on charcoal hemoperfusion.

response: I know what she's gonna say. She's gonna lie to save her business. Gimme more pills.

response: Bad mojo is not a diagnosis.

context: You really have to flash your private stash in front of me?

context: That's... unlikely. The charcoal would have absorbed a lot of the heparin. She's been anaemic. Could be a primary blood disorder.

What the hell, why don't we get a plumber in here, ask his opinion! Hey Cuddy, you know any rodeo clowns who can weigh in...!

context: I don't need you to cover my ass! What I need is my Vicodin! Two pills Every six hours. Like I'm on an allowance. She's given the cop lEverage over medical decisions! response: What's good about this rash?

context: It's on parts of her body that we haven't touched. She's got a fEver of a hundred-and-three. She's in and out of consciousness. But it's not a reaction to anything we did. Our mojo is off the table. Which means...?
response: Oh! So close. Means thanks to Cuddy's candy-ass approach, broad-spectrum antibiotics are no longer an option. This thing has grown horns and fangs. We gotta figure out what species it is. Go in with a spear to the heart.

context: Oh! So close. Means thanks to Cuddy's candy-ass approach, broad-spectrum antibiotics are no longer an option. This thing has grown horns and fangs. We gotta figure out what species it is. Go in with a spear to the heart.
response: Okay, you guys are sulking. I don't really care why, but apparently I can't do my job without finding out.

response: Horrible, horrible news. Wow! I'm glad we didn't let that fester. If she did have Reye's, then it could be varicella or associated...

context: He released our money. You do know what that means?
response: The correct question is "How can it be varicella given that she's not itchy?".

context: We weren't laughing with him.
response: Maybe he just gave up. Start the kid on chloramphenicol for Rocky Mountain Spotted FEver.

context: I really think you need...
response: Either you screwed me and you want absolution, or you didn't and you want applause. Either way, not interested.

response: It moves too quickly and we waited too long. We don't have time for a culture.

response: Get out of my office.

context: I did this to help you.

context: Knock it off. Look, I don't care why Doctor Wilson is doing this, and right now it makes no difference to you either, you need to deal with the reality of your current situation. You want to stand on principle, you end up in a cell, and you end up nEver practicing medicine again. So you got two choices - your principles, or your life.
response: Get out of my office.

context: Well the stitches are healing nicely, there's no sign of infection.

context: Doctor. Don't worry, I'll be firing him soon. Wait in my office.

context: Delightful, usually we just get the elf jokes this time of year.
response: "No" on trauma. Negative PPD. What flavour dwarfs are you guys?

context: My daughter and I both have cartilage hair hypoplasia; think you can make a pun out of that?
response: Yes, but I don't want to be insensitive. She's got a bit of a short fuse hasn't she?

context: It's a bleb, wait in my office.
response: Bleb's not a diagnosis, it's an evasion.

context: We'll schedule an MRI to make sure, but a certain number of these cases are idiopathic.
response: Let me translate that into Tolkien for you guys - means Doctor Cuddy's got no idea why your daughter's lung suddenly popped like a balloon.

context: Give me her chart, and my pills.
response: Santa needs us. Did you get that looked at?

context: What are you going to do?
response: I thought I'd get your theories, mock them, then embrace my own. The usual.

context: Wilson told us he ratted.
response: Your choice of verb I take it?

context: It's appropriate, he betrayed you. And you should take the deal.
response: Unexplained lung collapse and anaemia. Cuddy thinks it's idiopathic - Cuddy and "idiop" being the relevant parts of that sentence.

context: Can't be TB since Cuddy already ruled it out.
response: Then you'd be just as big an idiop as her. Don't you people know your dwarfs?

context: There are over 200 varieties of dwarfism, each with different medical complications; you can't expect us to be intimately familiar with all of them.
response: The sick dwarfs sure expect you to.

context: Cartilage hair hypoplasia - they have compromised immune systems.
response: Gold star for Cameron, for extra credit explain to the special needs section of the class why our Patient's negative TB test is irrelevant.

context: A PPD involves planting a fragment of TB under the skin to see if the immune system recognises it, because of her compromised immune system, our Patient could have TB but not recognise it.
response: The little people love you. Let's go see a dwarf about a gallium scan.

context: I'm 4' 1". That's 1.5 canes in metric.
response: You don't look a day over 4 feet. I saw in the file that her dad was normal size.

context: He grew up in the circus, said I reminded him of home. Seems like you're the one with the fetish.
response: Certainly curious about the logistics. Did you stand on a table?

context: I've dealt with worse. Being different, you get used to people's idiocy. Still beats the hell out of actually being an idiot. What?
response: Care to go for a spin?

context: Gallium scan shows no bright spots of any kind, means it's not TB or any other infection.
response: There are no bright spots because the whole thing is too bright. Except for the liver.

context: Could be lung cancer. Tumour causes structural damage, lung caves in on itself, also explains the anaemia.
response: Doesn't explain the liver pRoblem though.

context: Her lung collapsed, there is no liver pRoblem.
response: Did you guys look at the liver on this thing?

context: You saying her liver's shutting down because the lighting is off? You just don't want a cancer diagnosis because then you'd have to deal with Wilson.
response: Lung cancer is a lame diagnosis. Avoiding Wilson is an added bonus.

context: House, we need to talk.
response: Not taking the deal. Glad we talked. Ultrasound her liver.

context: House, you're off the case. Your treatment privileges are suspended until you accept Tritter's deal.
response: Well I'm obviously not going to take the deal just so I can have the fun of treating a dwarf so I assume there's more to this threat.

context: I'm taking over as attending. Get an MRI of her lungs.
response: This is not lung cancer.

context: We'll find out as soon as we MRI her lungs.
response: You're going to come begging me to save this girl long before I come begging you for pills.

context: Liver biopsy was negative for cirrhosis but it shows sclerosing cholangitis. Even weirder, there's no increase in alkaline phosphotates.
response: Hmm... medical mystery. Sounds like the kind of thing I'd be good at. Breaking and entering sounds like the kind of thing you'd be good at.

context: If that were true, more than her lungs and liver would be affected.
response: It will be. It'll spread through the biliary tree and hit her pancreas next. Stop retracing your steps, get ahead of it. Forget the liver and focus on the pancreas 'coz after that... actually after that, it doesn't really matter what it is because all roads lead to a dead dwarf.

context: I get why you don't want to go to rehab but only an idiot goes to prison for being stubborn.
response: Only an idiot stands between Ahab and his whale. Move.

context: Hmm, bones are aligned properly. Which ER did you go to after the car accident?
response: Princeton-Plainsborough. Here's my discharge slip.

context: Okay, going to get you some acetaminophen with codeine.
response: I err... I tried that, it makes me nauseous.

context: Err... there's a drug called gabapentin which is good for certain kinds of pain.
response: Great, I haven't slept in days.

context: Gabapentin's not really going to help with the sleep.
response: Oh. Is there something else you could give me?

context: Unfortunately our policy forbids prescribing opiates to new Patients.
response: How can a clinic have a rule against relieving pain?

context: Just for the opiates, we find that it helps weed out drug-seekers.
response: You think I'm a drug-seeker?

context: I just said I didn't.
response: No, you said that the policy was to stop drug-seeking. Then you said I'm not a drug-seeker, policy doesn't apply.

context: I'm sorry, that's the policy.
response: Gabapentin works on nerve damage; you're prescribing it for a broken face! Might as well hand out band aids for a sEvered carotid!

context: You were right; the Patient's pancreas is failing.
response: Told you you'd come begging me for help.

context: Her insulin production is almost non-existent.
response: Give me my pills, or lose an arm.

context: Take the deal and I will.
response: You'd rather kill this girl than give me my pills?

context: I would rather lose one Patient now than the dozens we will lose while you're in prison.
response: Well have fun explaining that to her itsy bitsy grieving mother.

context: House, these cuts are straight in a row. You did this on purpose.
response: Cutting releases endorphins, endorphins reliEve pain. Can you get me some pills?

context: You really think she's going to fold?
response: Autoimmune fits better than cancer but lupus floods kidneys, usually attacks them first. Kidneys are fine, right?

context: Yeah. House, take the deal. You can survive without vicodin. After you were shot you stayed clean for months.
response: Yeah, only it had something to do with the absence of pain. No leave that, I want to be able to pour alcohol on it so I can distract myself.

context: Got a history of ear infections.
response: You see Abigail's immune system is like a shy guy in a bar. The ear infections - they come in, they try to coax him to... to hell with the metaphor. You get the point right?

context: Nerd gets drunk, thrashes the bar. One of the autoimmunes triggered by a minor infection.
response: Factor in her age, elevated sed rate, anaemia... it's Still's disease. Start her on prednisone, methotrexates, cyclosporin.

context: Yeah, clearly the drugs have no hold on you.
response: We both know that my pride far surpasses my instinct for self-preservation. You want to redeem yourself, give up now.

context: And you'll go to jail.
response: Which makes this your last chance to do me a kindness before ruining my life forEver. Nausea's bad this time. You write me a script for Metoclopramide so I can stop puking. They'd give me that in rehab.

context: Trying to embarrass me in front of a grieving widow crosses lines that Even--
response: Right, I'm pathetic. I'm strung out, I haven't slept, puking Every hour and I still out-diagnosed you. But I'm supposed to let you decide what's best--

context: It's not her heart, she's bleeding.
response: Picking up a script for Zebalusky.

context: This is err... doctor Wilson's Patient.
response: Yeah, Wilson's busy right now what with Mr Zebalusky dying in agony on account of his metastatic lung cancer and not having the pills to reliEve that agony because of some moron pharmacist.

context: I've got spinal muscular atrophy.
response: At least it's not contagious. Nice bear.

context: You win, you can have vicodin.
response: Words have set meanings for a reason, you see an animal like Bill and you try to play fetch, Bill's going to eat you because Bill's a bear.

context: It's between cancer and autoimmune.
response: See that's what we call a faulty syllogism. Just because you call Bill a dog doesn't mean that he is... ... a dog. We've got to x-ray our Patient's leg.

context: Did you just take a pill?
response: No. So how does a dwarf have completely normal growth plates?

context: How Many pills have you taken?
response: Not nearly as Many as I'm gonna take. Forgotten how delicious they were.

context: I didn't give them to him.
response: Can we forget my vices and get back to my virtues? We were missing the fact that just because we called her a dwarf doesn't mean she is a dwarf. Everyone assumed she was because of her mother and there's no test for CHH dwarfism so she lost an identity but we've gained a symptom.

context: So what connects a long-term pituitary issue with pRoblems in the lungs, liver and pancreas?
response: Oh you guys and your bickering. Cancer versus autoimmune.

context: Obviously you think it's something else.
response: Nope, I think it's both. Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis - also known as you've got your cancer in my autoimmune disease. The immune component responded to the Still's treatment, led to the short-term improvement, the cancer portion didn't.

context: We dismissed this earlier because there were no neurological symptoms.
response: Yeah... it's not your fault, the only neurological symptom was her height. Who could have noticed?

context: Yeah... it's not your fault, the only neurological symptom was her height. Who could have noticed?
response: This is your pituitary gland and this is the granuloma that's been crushing it. No pituitary equals no growth hormone equals... about that much.

context: And then what? What will happen to her then?
response: Let me see if I can make this clear. This pill represents... a pill. And my mouth represents your daughter's mouth. We deposit the pill in the mouth. You may nEver be tall enough to play in the WNBA but you should be able to post up your mom no pRoblem.

context: What if I don't take the pills? What if you remove the thing in my head and give me the chemo but not the pills? Would I still get better?
response: Your body needs growth hormone for lots of things like... to grow.

context: I like who I am now.
response: Nobody your age likes who they are now.

context: Can't you deliver a diagnosis without making her feel that her life isn't worth living?
response: I'm trying to help her.

context: You're trying to make her taller.
response: Not too tall. Just tall enough to wipe her own butt.

context: If my daughter doesn't want to choose the easy path, I won't force her to.
response: Then you're a lousy mom. You want your daughter to be a freak.

context: Being little is not the same--
response: You and I have found that being normal sucks because we're freaks. Advantage of being a freak is that it makes you stronger. How strong do you really want her to have to be? Tell her what you have to tell her, now you tell her you lied, Even if you didn't.

context: Thought you might prefer people over pills.
response: Hey mom, I guess you guys are already up at Aunt Sarah's. I'm sure dad's in the eggnog and you're pRobably suffering through another dried out turkey. Just wanted to say Merry Christmas.

context: House? Are you okay? I called 3 times.
response: I'm ready to take the deal.

context: You're going to go talk to him?
response: I was just going to ask him where he gets his haircut.

context: Except that he wasn't the Patient or the doctor, he was the guy who stole from the Patient and the doctor. This was the 3rd time he's been disorientated in the last 2 weeks.
response: Running into smoke filled burning buildings can be a bit disorienting. Fortunately I have the cure, stop doing it.

context: A hypothalamic tumour can cause vacillating temperatures.
response: So could ER nurses who were too busy to notice that a Patient likes both hot coffee and cold sodas

context: He tested negative for Hep C, TB, HIV, Lyme and his tox screen's clean.
response: In case you hadn't noticed, not exactly in the mood to dance.

context: I'm not asking you to dance, I'm asking you to do your job.
response: EKG showed arrhythmia, pRobably just a mild heart attack.

context: He was in the burn unit for six months and had multiple surgeries, could be a hospital acquired infection maybe MRSA.
response: Works for me, draw blood cultures start him on antibiotics, Vancomycin plus broad gram-negative coverage.

context: Works for me, draw blood cultures start him on antibiotics, Vancomycin plus broad gram-negative coverage.
response: If you called to see the design for my prison tatts, they're still at R and D.

context: You need to talk to Tritter.

response: Yeah, you know what else Tritter can do?

context: You're not impressing anyone. You may call yourself principled but what you really are is a stubborn adolescent idiot! This isn't his fault.
response: I'm not the one who--

context: He's seeing blue where'd you get the script from?
response: Cuddy. Wanna know what I gave her?

context: Yes, his age is the reason it's weird that a Man has menopause.
response: Male menopause, high oestrogen, low testosterone, explains temperature swings, disorientation, endocrinologically similar to female menopause but without the vaginas and mah-jong tiles.

context: Male menopause doesn't explain the vision.
response: Blue vision isn't a symptom, it's a side effect of Viagra, it's right there on the label, which I have no reason to have read except that I'm a doctor, but then...

context: He's presenting no other signs of premature aging.
response: Aging's not the only cause, you said he's got burns to 54 of his body, sure it's not 55?

context: Burns to his genitals could cause testicular trauma.
response: Which could in turn cause...

context: Which could in turn cause...
response: Run a hormone panel, comes back positive pump him full of testosterone and send him home. And stop following me.

context: Complaint department's across the hall I'm busy, can I just assume that you told me how unfair I'm being and...
response: I'm sorry... You could throw a dart at all the adjectives between arrogant and unhinged and I'm sure you'd hit one that describes me. There's a reason I operate that way... I live in pain. Pain that on good days is merely intolerable and on bad ones will suck the life-force right out of you. Doesn't mean that I've handled this right, actually, means I was wrong.

context: Thank you. I know that couldn't have been easy for you to say. Even if you don't mean a word of it.
response: I'm sorry! You can hook me up to a damn polygraph.

context: That's it, no challenging our theory, no tearing us down.
response: No need, you got it under control.

context: Did Tritter offer you another deal?
response: Nope, this is all me. So no slaps on the back? Encouraging words...

context: We are just trying to understand what this is.
response: I hope this is me detoxing, otherwise I soiled a perfectly good pair of underwear last night for nothing.

context: So this is for real, this is not just a show for Tritter?
response: Absolutely it's a show for Tritter, and the Judge, unfortunately unless it's real, there is no show. Hey if it doesn't help my case at least I'll go to prison with heightened senses, all the better to enjoy my strolls around the yard.

context: Going to need to check that stuff.
response: When I lead the big Patient rebellion, Voldemort here is the first to go.

context: He may nEver be ready, you're doing the only thing you can do, keep trying. How about you Greg? You thought about how to fix things with people in your life?
response: No need, people in my life have no expectations of me, makes all our lives easier.

context: Apparently not. The first step in recovery...
response: Is admitting I have a pRoblem, I've obviously already done that or I wouldn't be here. I've Even embraced step 2, I've admitted there's a higher power, may not be a god per se... but that Andre the giant guy was powerful. Where I start to butt up against it is step 3, surrendering my will to this higher power. I'm sure Andre's ghost has my back and all but my free will, I nEver leave home without it.

context: We don't have an answer yet.
response: I'm fine by the way, thanks for asking! WhoEver came up with buprenorphine to wean off Vicodin should be shot. And then stabbed in the eye I think someone needs to adjust my meds!

context: The heart shows no sign of inflammation or...
response: The cause of the heart attacks isn't internal it must be external, something environmental.

context: None of the attacks happened in the same place.
response: Still must be something in common.

context: His clothes were all different he'd been cleaned.
response: That's the what's, how bout the who's?

context: People don't cause heart attacks.
response: Well then you should be worried about proving me wrong.

context: We were clearing rooms in an office building fire, the ceiling collapsed and it cut me off from the rest of the group. I kept yelling that I was fine but Derek refused to wait for the team to clear the Debris so he took off looking for another access point. He got caught in a back draft. He almost died because of me once. And now it's happening again.
response: You're not my mom, you don't have to keep checking up on me.

context: See this big fancy wing? It was built because this program works
response: Faulty logic. This big fancy wing exists because some people with money think that it works. They wanna beliEve that they can buy a better world. This is nothing short of idealised despair, let people wallow in it.

context: I don't Even know what that means.
response: None of this means anything. It's just nonsensical slogans and platitudes.

context: Meaning takes time. It takes work.
response: What do you think I've been doing?

context: You've been here for two days! Talk about wallowing in it. We all get it, we know how much pain you have. You're here to deal with that and get on with your life.
response: Right! I should have an affair with a dying Patient and move into a hotel.

context: You're a coward House. You find fault in Everybody because you're afraid to look at yourself.
response: Thanks, I was running short on platitudes, you can leave now.

context: But if you're too worried about losing your job to get it treated they can dEvelop into full on heart attacks, you think it's a coincidence this started when Amy got engaged?
response: No I don't, but now that you know the why what are you going to do to stop the how?

context: We need to put him on antidepressants.
response: Not if you're right. Antidepressants would inhibit his autonomic nervous system, which would only speed up the heart attacks.

context: We could try propylthiouracil, slow down his metabolic rate.
response: Thyroid effect would only weaken the heart.

context: Only other option is blood thinners.
response: This is not a fat guy with plaque-filled arteries and a swollen heart, he's a guy who's brain is trying to kill his heart.

context: The guy's heart isn't working and you want to shock his brain?
response: Electroshock therapy is the only way to erase his memories of Amy and stop the brain's chemical attack on the heart.

context: Antidepressants would inhibit his autonomic nervous system, speed up the attacks.
response: LMNO, PTU, blood thinners, none of them would solve this pRoblem. He's got a real-life harlequin roMance in his head, were going to pull out the 1940s playbook. Bilateral electrodes, high stimulus sine wave intensity, turning that dial all the way to 11. It's basic brain chemistry, we interrupt protein synthesis altering the neurotransmitter system, the result, no memories, no Amy, no pRoblem.

context: What are you talking about?
response: If I'd pitched electroshock therapy as a cure for broken heart syndrome any other time, you'd have dug in and maybe tried another 100 useless things first. So either you're actually beginning to trust me or... you just feel sorry for me.

context: Cuddy wouldn't get off the phone until I promised I'd come see for myself. I gotta admit, this move I did not expect.
response: Well don't tell anyone but the photos of smiling people in the brochures, it's just marketing.

context: Well you're obviously making an effort. So I suppose the next step is for me to talk to the DA.
response: Which you have no intention of doing.

context: So words mean nothing, actions mean nothing, what the hell is left?
response: You son of a bitch! What about your words, your actions. Gotta get House cleaned up, get him to show some humility, when it comes to actually doing something you prove that all you care about is bitch slapping a guy who refused to kiss your ass.

context: You Ever trust an addict? You Ever give one the benefit of the doubt? How Many times did it work out for you?
response: Yeah yeah yeah, I get it, so you were screwed over by your mother, your wife, your partner, but you keep sending them Christmas cards while you take it out on Everyone else.

context: I'm going to stay here, monitor Derek.
response: Thanks for the update. My next condolence call is arriving, I'll see you guys tomorrow

context: I figured it might help make a good impression on the Judge.
response: It's not that nice... I had no business blaming you for any of this. I know you were just trying to help me, protect me, that's what friends do.

context: His blood's normal and his heart's pumping it up to the brain
response: But it's not all getting there, something's obstructing the blood flow.

context: Do you want to go to jail?
response: No thank you. Set him up for a selective vertebral angiography, I'm on my way.

context: Are you out of your mind?
response: They said they wanted me there, but I don't think they liked me. His voice isn't high because of the electrical charges; it's another symptom of menopause. His system keeps getting hit by women's issues, so let's follow the pattern. What might obstruct the blood flow that's more common in women than men? Is the catheter in?

context: Go back to court, we will let you know the results.
response: Shut up and wire him.

context: Shut up and wire him.
response: Centre the image in the interpeduncular cistern, keep it moving at 30 frames per second.

context: You think the arteries are narrowing; you're going to need still shots which WE can do without you.
response: The pRoblem is not how wide the road is, it's a guy with a squeegee on the sidewalk, flagging cars. That's what's causing the slowdown, we find him we find the pRoblem.

context: Injecting the dye. Blood's in the capillaries.
response: There! Mr Squeegee, spinal meningioma, pushing on the nerves to the vocal chords. Creates the voice change and that nerve just happens to live right near the meningeal branch of the vertebral artery, obstructs the blood flow to the brain, brain malfunctions creating false memories, memories cause love, love kills. And we didn't completely screw up; cleaning the slate bought us time to find the real pRoblem. On the other hand, if we'd been better we wouldn't have needed the time. Schedule him for surgery, dig that thing out and he can start enjoying real misery instead of the fake stuff.

context: House I just heard that you apologised to Wilson.
response: Detoxing, I didn't know what I was saying.

context: Detoxing, I didn't know what I was saying.
response: Excuse me I have to go to jail.

context: I hope you don't mind that we continued on without you?
response: I said I was sorry there's no need to be sarcastic.

context: Surprised to see you're not spooning your way through the walls.
response: So what do you say? How about a conjugal visit to celebrate?

context: Well, if you don't remember, then how can you

She was fine until she started the long-distance running. The ultra-marathoning modified her immune system, set off the allergic reaction. We did a full thickness skin graft, and she'll be okay.

response: Who don't need to be diagnosed. They just need to be bandaged. What causes syncope?

context: Unless it's just conjunctive coagulopathy from the trauma.

context: Okay. Okay, they're telling me I have to go.

context: You know who's Even luckier? You and just about Every other huMan being who wasn't down there.

response: Yeah. That must be it. It's not that you're a pathetic narcissist.

context: No. You said... that there was time.

context: How bad will it hurt?

context: I don't know. Ten minutes. He was being questioned when he fell into the coma.

Which distracted us from the fact that it could have been just a clog in his sewer pipe, and by that, of course, I mean his spinal cord. And blah, blah, blah, blah. You get the idea.

response: Breath sounds bilaterally. It's not another pneumothorax. Neck vein's flat. There's no tamponade. Damn it, I went in too high. Hanna, you've got a clot in your lung. I'm gonna fix this. IV streptokinase.

response: Her body won't get any oxygen unless we can bust the clot. This is a blood thinner.

response: It's gonna make her bleed more. We'll take care of that next.

response: It's not busting the clot.

response: How do I know I'm not hallucinating?

Now either that's the cane, or I just ruptured one of those liver cysts we were chatting about and you've gone into anaphylactic shock, exactly the same as your son did when he accidentally tripped against my friend's car. The steroids and the immuno-suppressants acted like a big hunk of dam across the river. Physics 101, put a dam up in front of a raging river, the river rises. By stopping the immuno-suppressants, we blew up the dam, and a hundred foot wall of bacteria flooded her lymph nodes.

So the question becomes, what type of bacterial infection affects huMans and not rats, and the huMan body would be unlikely to recognize.

context: Exactly like the cop and exactly like Foreman. And what if the Patient was then exposed to a second infection, like legionella? context: Pain makes us make bad decisions. Fear of pain is almost as big a motivator. Now look, we still have time. I will do that biopsy if I have to, but not a moment before.

Her body couldn't absorb enough niacin, caused the pellagra. Didn't absorb vitamin K, caused the bleeding. And celiac is why the baby's meds didn't work. His body just couldn't absorb them.
